Award.AwardTitle: Mathematically Guided Experiments of Lung Mucus Transport Properties
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project integrates a set of experiments, guided and analyzed by mathematics, to probe and infer diffusive and flow transport properties of lung airway mucus. The set of experiments and corresponding instruments are necessary to span the spectrum of biologically relevant length, time and force scales for lung mucus flow and particle diffusion within. Mucus layers are propelled by individual cilia, coordinated waves of cilia, as well as by laminar and turbulent airflow. The diffusion of inhaled viruses, bacteria, environmental particulates and drug carrier particles in lung mucus is observed to depend, indeed dramatically so, on particle size relative to the mesh size distribution of mucus and on particle electrostatic interactions with the mucus gel. Furthermore, the biophysical properties of lung mucus vary across populations and with disease progression in an individual. This project lays out a strategy to overcome the myriad limitations of current approaches to mucus transport characterization. Individual projects will advance experimental design and diagnostics, inference methods from experimental data, and direct modeling and simulation tools. Flow transport projects combine wave-theoretical methods, inertial extensions of standard creep rheology, and stochastic bead-bead fluctuations in order to span the requisite length, time and force scales. Diffusive transport is inherently stochastic, for which new models and simulation tools are outlined to model and predict the transient anomalous diffusive properties that are experimentally observed. All projects are designed consistent with the functions that mucus performs in lung biology, and the integrated experimental-mathematical tools are designed for clinical applicability to mucus samples. The tools and approach are developed and tested on two mucus simulants, hyaluronic acid solutions and agarose gels, whose properties can be tuned a priori and independently tested with standard rheological instruments and theory.

This project develops the underpinnings of a new approach to lung health assessment and treatment of disorders and diseases. The present approach is to treat symptoms based on the statistics of clinical trials and accumulated empirical evidence. Mechanically, lung infections are the result of a failure of airway mucus to trap, transport and clear pathogens or environmental particulates. Thus the flow of mucus layers by the action of cilia and airflow, and the diffusion of diverse particles within the mucus layer, are the fundamental mechanisms that underlie lung health. Contrary to popular belief, antibodies provide a secondary line of defense. The tools and mathematical theory for assessment, prediction, and understanding of flow and diffusive transport of lung mucus layers in biologically relevant conditions do not exist. This project incorporates existing experimental methods, instruments, and mathematical theory with the design and construction of new instruments, mathematical theory and numerical algorithms. When integrated, these tools will provide the capability to infer flow and diffusive transport properties of mucus samples from an individual patient, and the capability to test physical and drug therapies to reinstate mucus clearance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our experimental-theoretical team has made advances with respect to the two fundamental transport processes of lung mucus:  flow and clearance of mucus from the airways, and the passive diffusion of inhaled particulates, pathogens, or drug carrier particles in airway mucus layers.  Using macrorheology and microrheology experiments, we constructed the most faithful rheological model of lung mucus to date, we developed algorithms and code to simulate the model and predict the flow of mucus in human bronchial epithelial cell cultures as well as the uptake distribution of drugs deposited at the air-mucus interface, we developed advanced Bayesian and maximum likelihood statistical tools to rank all candidate models for anomalous diffusion of particles in mucus and to perform inverse parameter fitting of those models, and finally we applied the diffusive transport tools to develop quantitative assessment metrics for lung disease and disease progression.  We identified a new clinical biomarker, weight percent of solids in mucus samples, and showed that microbead rheology reveals a quantitative metric of mucus biophysical properties as the weight percent of solids increases.  These research projects were carried out in a multidisciplinary collaboration between applied mathematicians, statisticians, probabilists, physicists, and clinical medical scientists.  A host of undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral scholars, junior and mid-career and senior faculty participated extensively in many research projects and publications over the course of the award.  All of these supported scholars have advanced to the next level of study (undergrad to grad, grad to postdoc, postdoc to either tenure-track faculty or private sector jobs, including new startups, and junior faculty to successful pre-tenure reviews and tenure decisions.  The experimental-theoretical methods developed over the life of the award are being used today in clinical trials and medical research collaborations.  These experimental-theoretical methods have furthermore been turned into graduate training curricula in modules developed and taught by the award PIs with significant contributions from graduate students and postdocs.

Addendum # 1

An integrated mathematical-experimental approach was developed to robustly characterize the biophysical properties of human lung mucus. The function of mucus is to trap inhaled particulates and pathogens while coordinated cilia and air drag from tidal breathing or cough propel mucus toward the larynx to be swallowed, thereby clearing the invasive load. In many respiratory disorders,the weight percent of solids in mucus increases. These changes alter both the diffusion of foreign objects in the mucus barrier as well as the ability of cilia and air drag to propel mucus. The overall goal of this grant was to develop experimental methods paired with and informed by mathematical modeling and predictive simulations to discern healthy and unhealthy mucus on the basis of their diffusive and flow transport properties.The theoretical-experimental team produced the most powerful diagnostic tools available for diffusive and flow transport properties of mucus, in health and during disease progression. The outcomes were achieved through a multidisciplinary team effort consisting of the principal investigators, their postdoctoral scholars, graduate and undergraduate students from the STEM disciplines of Mathematics and Physics, as well as researchers from the Marsico Lung Institute at UNC Chapel Hill. The project benefitted from independently funded mathematics and statistics collaborators from Harvard University, Tulane University, the University of South Carolina, and the University of Waterloo. High-profile publications, conference presentations, and invited lectures provided broad dissemination of the results of the grant.The following project outcomes stand out. It is difficult to obtain physiologically relevant mucus samples in the volumes required by traditional rheological techniques. Further, mucus from bronchial airway lavages and induced sputum are diluted to uncontrolled degrees, thereby casting uncertainty on the pure mucus properties. As such, there was no rigorous lung mucus standard of healthy to diseased states, and no biophysical property metrics, by which to compare any individual mucus sample. All literature results were from experiments on poorly characterized clinical samples with no knowledge of the modification in experimental measurements due to dilution and variation of mucus concentration, quantified by weight percent (wt%) of solids.The Hill lab has pioneered the use of mucus harvested from human bronchial epithelial (HBE) cell cultures grown and maintained in the lab. By controlling the concentration of mucus produced by the cultures, HBE mucus can be tuned between 2 wt% solids that typify healthy airways to pathological mucus concentrations of 4-10 wt% and above found in genetic and acquired pulmonary diseases.These controlled mucus samples serve as an assay with which to compare biophysical properties of clinical mucus via passive microbead rheology.The mathematical tools developed to analyze microbead position time series (particle paths)revealed a remarkable scaling behavior in the anomalous sub-diffusive statistics of HBE culture mucus vs wt% solids. From this “library” of microbead diffusion metrics, clinical samples can now be analyzed and placed within this library, providing a clinical biomarker for detection of healthy to diseased mucus. The theoretical methods further allow the ability to infer beads in pure salt water and in the least dilute volume of the sample. The latter reflect in vivo conditions present in airways,previously impossible to isolate and rheologically quantify. The mathematical tools included Bayesian methods to rank models based on the experimental data and maximum likelihood estimators of the parameters in all candidate models. The mathematical team developed new methods to remove uncertainty due to experimental drift that distorts the inferred physical properties.Furthermore, highly efficient direct simulation algorithms were developed. Combined, these advances allow, for the first time, the ability to perform microbead tracking experiments, identify a best-fit model to the data, infer the diffusion and drift parameters of the model from the data, then simulate the best-fit model to reconstruct the experimental particle paths, and finally predict passage time distributions of anomalous sub-diffusion through airway mucus barriers.The macro and micro rheology experiments were used to generate the first rheologically faithful characterization of human lung mucus, from which the team constructed fully nonlinear constitutive models for mucus flow transport. Numerical algorithms for these constitutive equations were derived and then simulated to give a foundational step toward mucus transport in HBE cell cultures. The dome shape of the air-mucus interface was captured by the computational model, and the diffusion-advection of small molecule drugs deposited at the air-mucus interface was simulated to illustrate heterogeneous uptake by the underlying epithelial tissue.

The experimental-theoretical methods developed over the life of the award are being used today in clinical trials and medical research collaborations. These experimental-theoretical methods have furthermore been turned into graduate training curricula in modules developed and taught by the award PIs with significant contributions from graduate students and postdocs.
